title: 'Shark Tank' recap: Vegan fried-chicken entrepreneurs wouldn't bite on Mark Cuban's offer
text:
CLOSE 'Shark Tank' sharks Mark Cuban, Daymond John, Barbara Corcoran, Kevin O' Leary, and Lori Greiner reflect on the show's growth since its 2009 premiere. Harrison Hill, USA TODAY

On Sunday’s “Shark Tank,” there was no winner winner, chicken dinner for two fried-chicken entrepreneurs. They turned down a dream of a lifetime.

Jonathan and Deborah Torres are the creators of Atlas Monroe, a product that may taste a lot like chicken but isn’t. Made with wheat, it’s a vegan twist on the fried chicken formula that left the sharks surprised.

“This batter is extremely tasty,” shark Lori Greiner said. “It’s got some zip to it.”

After Deborah’s father was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes, the whole family decided to switch to a raw vegan diet. Ninety days later, they were in the kitchen trying to develop better-tasting food.

Jonathan and Deborah Torres, entrepreneurs from San Jose, California, with a plant-based version of fried chicken make a shocking decision on "Shark Tank" Oct. 6. (Photo: Jessica Brooks, ABC)

Last week: 'Shark Tank' recap: Frozen-food entrepreneur gets a warm reception from hungry sharks

“We grew very hangry at each other from eating salads and fruit salads,” Deborah said.

Starting off at festivals, the company has now begun shipping frozen products nationwide. But their reluctance to share sales figures didn’t win the two an ally in Shark Kevin O’Leary: “It’s never good when you don’t give us the numbers, you know that?”

“We have celebrities,” Deborah said. “We have influencers vouching for us, telling the world it’s the best they ever had without us ever paying anyone a dime. We were the first and only vegan company to be invited to the National Fried Chicken Festival.”

According to Deborah, their yearly sales were $63,000, net sales were $70,000, and gross sales were $76,000

The numbers confused the sharks.

“Wait that doesn’t add up,” shark Mark Cuban said. “Your numbers are backwards. You can’t have $70,000 in sales and make $63,000.”

For O’Leary and fellow shark Barbara Corcoran, the confusion, along with a high valuation, was too much.

'Shark Tank' secrets: Life-changing moments on an assembly line of product pitches

Mark Cuban, who says he went vegetarian three months ago, was ready to offer a deal on Sunday's "Shark Tank." (Photo: Dan MacMedan, USA TODAY)

“Asking for $500,000 for 10% is ridiculous,” O’Leary said. “You’re not that clear with your numbers. Just being honest with you. You’re not worth $500,000. I’d have to have 120% of the company.”

Corcoran thought they came on the show too early into their business: “If you were to come here and have orders or some proof. You have compliments and intent, but you don’t have orders.”

The Torreses insisted they did have orders, as well as a potential deal with a mega restaurant to push their product. That along with their margins was enough for Cuban to offer them a deal.

“I went vegetarian three months ago,” Cuban said. “This is important to me. I love products I can eat.”

Cuban initially offered them $500,000 as a line of credit for 30% of business, but he then decided to partner with guest shark Rohan Oza. Their offer was $1 million for the entire company with a 10% royalty for the Torreses. They would do all the heavy lifting and put up any financing Atlas Monroe needed.

“This is an amazing moment in 'Shark Tank' history,” O’Leary said. “You came in with a very confusing pitch. Now you have a million-dollar offer by two behemoths who can execute.”

But the Torreses weren’t willing to give up their company. They turned down the deal, leaving O’Leary scratching his head.

“The fact you guys are even offering a million dollars let’s me know you do understand what we are worth,” Deborah said.

As they walked away empty-handed, Jonathan promised viewers would see them on “Shark Tank” again one day: “We're probably going to be there sitting next to them soon.”
